Christiane Amanpour Biography | Wiki

Christiane Amanpour is a popular and skilled American journalist currently working at CNN where she serves as a chief international anchor of the network’s award-winning, flagship global affairs program “Amanpour,” In addition, the program also airs on PBS in the United States. Nonetheless, she is also the host of “The Amanpour Hour,” a Saturday show consisting of forensic interviews with the newsmakers, game changers, and cultural icons shaping our world.

Christiane Amanpour Family | Parents

She was born in the West London suburb of Ealing in the United Kingdom in the year 1958 to a loving and caring father and mother. Furthermore, she is the daughter of Mohammad Taghi Amanpour (father) and Ann Patricia Hill (mother). In addition, her mother is Irish while her father is Iran. Moreover, she grew up in Tehran until the age of eleven. Not to mention, that Christiane was she baptized at the Church of Saint Benedict in Ealing.

Christiane Amanpour Education Background

Nevertheless, after her High School education, she enrolled at the University of Rhode Island. Later, she graduated from the University with a Bachelor of Arts in Journalism.

Christiane Amanpour CNN

Where is Christiane Amanpour working now? She is currently employed at CNN as a chief international anchor of the network’s award-winning, flagship global affairs program “Amanpour,” Furthermore, she is also the host of “The Amanpour Hour,” a Saturday show consisting of forensic interviews with the newsmakers, game changers and cultural icons shaping our world. Not to mention, that she is based in the network’s London bureau.

Nevertheless, since she began her career at CNN, she has managed to secure exclusive interviews with global power players. In the wake of the September 11 attacks, she was the first international correspondent to interview British Prime Minister Tony Blair, Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf, and Afghan President Hamid Karzai. In addition, while in the Arab Spring Anmnpour conducted an Emmy-winning interview, the last, with Libya’s former leader ‘Colonel Moammar Gadhafi, she was also the last journalist to interview Egypt’s President Hosni Mubarak just before he was deposed.

Additionally, she has received every major television journalism award including fourteen News and Documentary Emmy Awards, four Peabody Awards, two George Polk Awards, three DuPont-Columbia Awards, and the Courage in Journalism Award.
